uvva.field module

class uvva.field.BaseField(field_id=0, field_name='None', ra=- 1, dec=- 1, observatory='None', obsfilter='None')

Bases: object

~uvva.field.BaseField provides class that defines the basic data structure for field-based analysis. One field is generally the area in the sky covered by an telescope in one observation. A field is generally composed of several visits of the telecope at different times.

This class contains the main funtionality for source detection and drawing. To be inherited by field analysis classes, which can then be tailored to the needs of the observatories supported by the UVVA pipeline.

__init__(field_id=0, field_name='None', ra=- 1, dec=- 1, observatory='None', obsfilter='None')
Parameters

  • field_id (int, optional) – Unique identifier number specifying the field. The default is 0.

  • field_name (str, optional) – Name of the field. The default is “None”.

  • ra (float, optional) – Right Assention of the field center in degrees. The default is -1.

  • dec (TYPE, optional) – Declination of the field center in degrees. The default is -1.

  • observatory (str, optional) – Observatory with which the data was taken. The default is “None”.

  • obsfilter (str, optional) – Observing filter at which the data was taken. The default is “None”.

Notes

Class atributes are of the tyooe astropy.Table. To see a description of each of them run BaseField.info().

Returns

Return type

None.

tt_visits

Astropy table with visit information

tt_visit_sources

Astropy table with visit source information

tt_sources

Astropy table with field sources information

tt_sources_mag

Astropy table with flux magnitude for each source and vist

tt_sources_s2n

Astropy table with signal to noise for each source and vist

tt_sources_ulmag95

Astropy table with 95% confidence upper limit magnitude

tt_list

List of attribute astropy tables

ra

RA of the field center in degrees (J2000)

dec

Dec of the field center in degrees (J2000)

get_ttcol_narray(tt_name, tt_var)
info()

Prints out information about the field, its visits and sources.

Returns

Return type

None.

class uvva.field.Field(parobs_id, cuts=None, refresh=False, verbose=False)

Bases: object

Instance of one GALEX field (coadd + visits)

Note in the MAST data base “obs_id” is equal to the “ParentImgRunID” of the visits table.

__init__(parobs_id, cuts=None, refresh=False, verbose=False)
get_variability_mask(level=3, project_to_coadd=False, info=False)

Computes bool-array masks for the catalog table according to the cut level.

l1: spatial separation of coadd and visit sources l2: signal-to-noise of the magnitude variation * l1 l3: absolute cut on the magnitude variation * l1 * l2

show_diff_map(field_name=None, id=None)
show_visit_statistics(key, coadd=True, bin_size=None, density=False, xscale=None, yscale=None, xlim_offset=None, figsize=(9, 3.5), label_fontsize=10)

Show histograms.

Valid keys are:

“s2n”: Signal-to-Noise “mag”: NUV magnitude “mag_err”: NUV magnitude uncertainty “dist”: Visit source distance to coadd sources “pos_err”: Photometric positional uncertainty “artifact”: GALEX catalog artifact ID

uvva.resource_manager module

class uvva.resource_manager.ResourceManager(verbose=False)

Bases: object

Manages access to external resources.

Resources like catalog files or large metadata files may be stored on remote storage systems such as DESY Sync & Share (SAS) or LUSTRE. Users may synchronize these resources onto their local systems to perform software analysis on the data. To aid collaborative development, the ResourceManager provides an interface to find the locations of resources on the user’s local system.

Parameters

verbose (bool, optional) – Enable verbose printout to stdout (default is False for no printout).

flags

Dictionary holding all flags.

Type

dict

metadata

Dictionary holding the parsed contents of the YAML-config files located at CLASSDIR/resource_metadata. Additional info my be added e.g. the set status of the env vars and the path they are pointing to.

Type

dict

get_path(resource, storage)

Get the path to a specific resource file or directory.

Notes

The implementation requires a set of environment variables. The full list of variables is defined in CLASSDIR/resource_metadata/resource_envs.yml. Users need to make sure these variables are known to the system. This can be achieved in two ways. Either the user manually sets each variable via the shell config file (.bashrc, zshrc, etc.) or the instance of ResourceManager automatically sets the variables if the config file at PACKAGEDIR/.env is found.

__init__(verbose=False)
get_path(resource, storage)

Returns the local path to a given resource at the corresponding storage system.

The path is constructed from the local path to the synced remote directory and the resource path relative to that directory.

Parameters

  • resource (str) – Name of the resource for which the path is requested.

  • storage (str) – Name of the storage system where resource is saved at.

Returns

path – Full local path to resource

Return type

str

Raises

  • KeyError – When either one of resource or storage names is not listed in resource_catalog.yml

  • ValueError – When the inference of the needed environment variable fails or the resource could not be found at the inferred path.

Notes

This method requires specific environment variables to be declared on the users system during runtime. The variable names are listed in CLASSDIR/resource_metadata/resource_envs.yml.

Examples

>>> rm = ResourceManager()
>>> rm.get_path(resource="gal_visits_list", storage="sas_cloud")
str(/local/path/to/resource.file)

uvva.utils module

uvva.utils.extr_value(inputlist, upper=False)

Computes the extremum value in a list of numeric lists upper = False: minimum (default) upper = True: maximum

uvva.utils.sky_sep2d(coords, seperation_limit=180)

computes 2D distances between all possible pairs of coordinates that are closer together than the separation limit (default: 180 -> all-sky)

if the all-sky case is set, the number of unique distance values is determined as follows: for the number of coordinates n = len(coords) a number of pairwise distances values N = 1/2 * (n-1)*n is returned

uvva.utils.get_time_delta(tt_visit_dates, unit=None)
uvva.utils.get_time_delta_mean(tt_visit_dates, unit=None, deviation=True)
